Metal-organic framework (MOF)-based composites have received significant attention for catalytic applications and are believed excellent heterogeneous catalysts. In this article, we prepared a new type of material, HPW@MOF-199/SBA-15C (PMS-15C). For this material, the MOF-199 encapsulating Keggin-type phosphotungstic acid (HPW) was grown inside the pores of the SBA-15 functionalized by carboxylic acids. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions, X-ray powder diffraction, transmission electron microscopy, and scanning electron microscopy analyses showed that the PMS-15C composites had an ordered two-dimensional hexagonal mesoporous structure, in which HPW encapsulating by MOF-199 loaded into the SBA-15C. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy indicated that HPW was successfully loaded, and the Keggin structure of HPW in PMS-15C remained unchanged. With the reaction of acetic acid and ethanol, the catalytic performance of PMS-15C was studied. Under the optimal conditions, ethyl acetate yield reached 81.4 %. The forward reaction rate was 0.432 mL mol−1 min−1, and the activation energy was 38.35 kJ mol−1. And the data were found to be consistent with the second-order reversible reaction kinetic model. The catalytic activity of the PMS-15C-0.2 composites remained stable after five catalytic cycles. In addition, the esterification of n-octanol/acetic acid and ethanol/oleic acid were studied using PMS-15C-0.2 as the catalyst. The results suggested that the catalytic activity of PMS-15C-0.2 was weakened upon increasing the substrates’ alkyl chain length. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords SBA-15 Phosphotungstic acid Encapsulation Esterification reaction MOF-199 Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Esters are organic compounds synthesized when an acid reacts with an alcohol [1]. Many esters formed from alcohols with branched chains are excellent lubricants, and esters are also used in industries such as flavors, fragrances, cosmetics, soaps, and pharmaceuticals [2]. Typically, the esterification of acid/alcohol to form the ester proceeds slowly and reversibly. Thus, in the view of improving the efficiency of esterification, catalysts are usually used. In the industrial production of esters, catalysts such as H2SO4 and HCl are often used [3]. However, these catalysts have the disadvantages of high toxicity, high corrosiveness, environmentally harmful, used in large quantities, and not easily to be recycled [4]. Therefore, researchers have focused on solid acid catalysts. Solid acid catalysts such as oxides, complex oxides, polymetallic oxides, and organic-inorganic hybrids are widely used in the petrochemical industry [5,6]. The use of polyoxometalates (POMs) in heterogeneous acid-catalyzed reactions is of high value from environmental and economic perspectives [7]. POMs consist of cationic and polyanionic clusters with diverse structures [8,9]. The structure and composition of POMs can be intentionally altered to obtain desired properties. The most common methods of realizing these modifications include polyhedral substitution, heteroatom substitution, and changes in the arrangement of the basic structural units. Although POMs have many different structures, Keggin-type POMs exhibit the highest Brønsted acidity and excellent catalytic activity in ester exchange, alkylation, hydrolysis, and other reactions [10]. Nevertheless, the high solubility in polar solvents of POMs present challenges in their recovery, significantly limiting their practical applications. In order to enhance their practical applications, POMs are often immobilized on different carriers [11–13], including titanium dioxide [14], silicon dioxide [15–17], zirconium dioxide [18], and MOFs [19,20]. In recent years, researchers have encapsulated POMs inside MOFs and used the resulting composites to catalyze esterification reactions [21]. Jiang et al. developed a new type of catalyst for the reaction of cyclohexene to cyclohexyl formate. The catalyst was prepared using a hydrothermal synthesis technique by incorporating HPW into MOF-199. When tested under optimized conditions, this catalyst achieved a conversion rate of 86.8 % and a selectivity of 84.2 % for cyclohexyl formate [22]. This demonstrates the potential for industrialization of this novel catalyst. Zhang et al. synthesized the HPW@MIL-100(Fe) catalysts using MIL-100(Fe) to encapsulate HPW. These catalysts demonstrate high catalytic performance in esterification and acetylation [23]. Unfortunately, the mechanical properties of POMs/MOFs are not high and the structure is easily damaged. In our preliminary research, using carboxyl-functionalized SBA-15 as a carrier, the MOF-199@SBA-15C composite material was successfully prepared [24]. As phosphotungstic acid (HPW) has a cluster diameter of about 1.2 nm [25] and can be encapsulated into the 1.3 nm-diameter cavity of MOF-199 [26]. In this work, HPW@MOF-199/SBA-15C composites were successfully synthesized. The composites were synthesized by hydrothermal synthesis, in which the HPW@MOF-199 self-constructed in SBA-15C. Through the esterification of ethanol/oleic acid, the catalytic activity and reusability of PMS-15C were systematically studied and the experimental data were kinetically fitted. In addition, the reaction substrates were expanded and the reactions of octanol/acetic acid and ethanol/acetic acid were studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials H3BTC (98.0 %), CH3COOH (99.0 %), C2H5OH (99.5 %), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (99.0 %), CH3(CH2)7CHCH(CH2)7COOH (99.0 %),CH3(CH2)7OH (99.0 %), CH3COOC2H5 (99.5 %), Si(OC2H5)4 (98.0 %), CH3(CH2)7CHCH(CH2)7COOC2H5 (98.0 %), CH3CO2(CH2)7CH3 (98.0 %), (HO)2P(O)CH2CH2COOH (98.0 %), and H3 [P(W3O10)4]·nH2O (AR) were purchased from Aladdin Biochemical Technology Company Limited. PEO20-PPO70-PEO20 (average Mn ∼ 5800) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Company Limited. HCl (36.0 ∼ 38.0 %) was purchased from Beijing Chemical Factory. All materials are ready to use without any handling. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of SBA-15 Under stirring, 2 g of P123 was soluble in 7.5 mL of H2O and 60 mL of 2 M HCl. The above mixture was stirred at for 24 h 35 °C after the addition of 4 g of ethyl orthosilicate. Then, the mixture was shifted to a Teflon-lined reactor and aged for 24 h at 100 °C. After the mixture had cooled naturally, it was filtered, washed several times, and the resulting product was vacuum-dried at 60 °C for 12 h. Finally, the dried solid was calcined for 10 h at 550 °C with a tube furnace to obtain the final product, labeled SBA-15. 2.2.2 Synthesis of SBA-15C SBA-15C was synthesized on the basis of SBA-15, but there were two differences. First, besides the addition of ethyl orthosilicate, 3-phosphopropionic acid was also added at the same time, wherein the molar ratio of 3-phosphopropionic acid/ethyl orthosilicate was 1:8. Second, SBA-15C was added to 400 mL ethanol which contained 5 mL HCl and stirred under reflux conditions for 24 h at 80 °C. This was used to extract the template agent. Finally, the product was washed a few times using ethanol and deionized water and was vacuum-dried for 12 h at 60 °C. 2.2.3 Synthesis of PMS-15C Dual active-site PMS-15C composites were synthesized by a solvothermal method, using the synthetic route shown in Scheme 1 . First, 0.085 g Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O was soluble in 5 mL H2O along with HPW of different doses, including 0.05, 0.1, 0.2 and 0.3 g, and then adding 0.2 g SBA-15C. After sonication for 30 min, the suspension was heated in a blast-oven for 5 h at 90 °C. After drying, the obtained solid were grinded and then washed with deionized water. Copper ions and phosphotungstic acid molecules not adsorbed by SBA-15C were removed by washing several times. Subsequently, 0.053 g H3BTC was dissolved in a liquid consisting of 10 mL ethanol water and 10 mL deionized, and the product obtained above was mixed with this solution. The above suspension was processed for 1 h on a magnetic stirrer and shifted to a high-pressure reactor with the Teflon-lined and aged for 12 h at 120 °C in a blast-oven. After the mixture had cooled naturally, it was filtered, washed several times. The resulting product was vacuum-dried at 60 °C for 12 h. A light blue solid powder was prepared and labeled PMS-15C-x, where x was 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, and 0.3, respectively, representing the amount of HPW added. 2.3 Characterization The ASAP-3020 (Micromertics, USA) was utilized to test samples for N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms. The Rigaku Smartlab x-ray diffractometer was utilized for x-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns with Cu K α radiation (λ = 0.154 nm), 45 kV, and 30 mA. The Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 was utilized to obtain Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR). The ESCALAB250Xi was utilized for X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS). JSM-7610F Plus was utilized to obtain scanning electron microscope (SEM) images of samples, and JEM-2000EX was utilized to obtain transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of samples. The Jobin-Yvon ULTIMA was utilized for Inductive Coupled Plasma Emission Spectrometer (ICP). Gas chromatography (GC-9600) was used to analyze the reaction products. 2.4 Esterification reactions and characterization The PMS-15C composites were investigated for catalytic properties and reusability by esterification reaction under the following experimental conditions and experimental steps. During the ethanol and acetic acid reaction, 0.1 mol ethanol and a certain amount of PMS-x were mixed in a flask with stirring. Then, 0.05 mol acetic acid was placed in the premixed solution at 60–100 °C for 12 h. Then catalyst was separated using a centrifuge and washed several times with ethanol and deionized water. Before being reused, it was treated at 120 °C for 3 h of activation. To ensure the reproducibility of the experiments, a minimum of three repetitions of all experiments were performed. The reaction of n-octanol/acetic acid involved mixing 0.1 mol n-octanol and catalyst in a flask with stirring. Then, 0.05 mol of acetic acid was placed in the premixed solution for 12 h at 60–100 °C. The reaction of ethanol/oleic acid involved mixing 0.1 mol ethanol and catalyst in a flask with stirring. Then, 0.05 mol of oleic acid was placed in the premixed solution, and the reaction time was 12 h at 60–100 °C. The products were detected by a GC-9600 with a flame ionization detector (FID). And A capillary column was used to separate the products. The column temperature was set at 75 °C with a hold time of 3 min. Then, depending on the reaction product, the temperature was raised to 150, 220 and 360 °C at 30 °C per minute and the holding time was 4 min. An internal standard method was used to calculate the yields of the products, where 1,3-butanediol (99.0 %) was the internal standard [27]. The Supplementary Material provided 1H NMR, elemental analysis and mass spectrometry data of ethyl oleate, octyl acetate and ethyl acetate. And the 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra of products were shown in Fig. S1-S3. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of PMS-15C-x The contents of Cu and W elements in the PMS-15C-x composites were determined using ICP and the calculation results were used to derive the loadings of MOF-199 and HPW in the composites. As presented in Table S1, the Cu and P content in the PMS-15C-x composites gradually decreased upon increasing the HPW addition. However, upon gradually increasing the amount of HPW, the decrease of Cu and P content gradually slowed down. As the addition of HPW increased from 0.2 g to 0.3 g, the Cu and P contents changed only slightly, indicating that the loadings of HPW in PMS-15C-x reached saturation. Previous research had shown that these two pore structures, A and B, were present in MOF-199 [26]. Pore A had a cubic surface and can accommodate Keggin anions, while pore B provided cubic spaces, but the copper-ligand water molecules were directed to the pore interior, which prevented Keggin anions from entering pore B [26]. This indicated that only half of the pores in MOF-199 could be used to load HPW molecules, as confirmed by the data in Table S1. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the samples are shown in Fig. 1 . MOF-199 exhibited a type I adsorption-desorption isotherm, while SBA-15C had a type IV adsorption-desorption isotherm accompanied by an H1 hysteresis loop in Fig. 1. A. Notably, MOF-199@SBA-15C and SBA-15 had the same type of adsorption-desorption isotherms and hysteresis loops. The PMS-15C-x composites displayed typical capillary coalescence within the range of P/P0 = 0.6–0.8, which indicated that the PMS-15C-x composites maintained their mesoporous structure. However, the maximum adsorption capacity decreased upon increasing the HPW addition, which indicated that the pores of SBA-15C were occupied by HPW@MOF-199. Barrett-Joyner-Halenda method was used to measure the pore size distribution. Fig. 1. B showed that the pore diameter decreased after loading MOF-199 and HPW, and the decrease in pore diameter was more obvious upon increasing the amount of HPW due to contraction of the mesoporous lattice and an increase in the components loaded into the pore channels of the SBA-15C carrier [28]. The BET specific surface area of the samples was shown in Table S2. The small angle XRD spectra of samples are presented in Fig. 2 . For SBA-15C and MOF-199@SBA-15C composites, three characteristic diffraction peaks appeared at 0.88°, 1.51°, and 1.73°, corresponding to the (100), (110), and (200) crystal planes. This suggested that both SBA-15C and MOF-199@SBA-15C had ordered 2D hexagonal mesoporous structures [29]. For the spectra of PMS-15C-x, although the (100), (110), and (200) crystal diffraction peaks also appeared at the same positions, their intensities were greatly weakened and further decreased upon increasing the HPW addition. Furthermore, the peak positions shifted. This indicated that the ordered mesoporous structure was preserved in PMS-15C-x, and HPW was immobilized in the pores of MOF-199, which decreased the scattering lining between the pores and pore walls of the composites [30]. Overall, the pore properties of SBA-15C were not altered by HPW, whereas PMS-15C-x retained the 2D hexagonal ordered mesoporous structure. The structures of samples were investigated using wide-angle XRD. Fig. 3 . A showed that the diffraction peaks at 6.7° (200), 9.5° (220), 11.6° (222), 13.4° (400), 14.7° (311), 16.5° (422), 17.5° (333), 19.0° (440), 20.2° (442), 24.1° (551), 26.0° (553), 29.2° (751), and 35.2° (951) were attributed to pure MOF-199 [31,32], and the broad peak near 25° belonged to amorphous silica. In comparison to MOF-199, the diffraction peaks of PMS-15C-0.2 exhibited significant differences in the range of 5–10° The peaks around 7° and 9° were significantly reduced in intensity [33], and the peaks at 13.4° and 19.0° disappeared, and new characteristic peaks emerged at 21.3°, 27.8°, 30.8°, 33.8°, and 37.8°, which indicated that SBA-15C and HPW affected the morphology and structure of MOF-199 [34,35]. However, for the PMS-15C-0.2 composites, no diffraction peaks of HPW crystals appeared, probably due to the fact that HPW was uniformly dispersed in MOF-199 and rather than aggregated [36]. Fig. 3. B shows the wide-angle XRD patterns of different samples. The intensity of the diffraction peaks at 27.9°, 30.7°, 33.9°, and 37.8° was enhanced upon increasing the HPW addition, and the other diffraction peaks did not change significantly, indicating no aggregation of HPW in the PMS-15C-x composites. However, in the previous ICP analysis, the HPW content in the PMS-15C-x composites increased with the amount of HPW added, indicating that HPW was highly dispersed. Fig. 4 shows the FTIR spectra of the different samples. For HPW and MOF-199, the characteristic peaks were the same as those the reported [34]. For MOF-199, the characteristic peaks at 1375, 1447, and 1638 cm−1 were attributed to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of carboxyl groups in H3BTC, respectively. Additionally, the peak at 730 cm−1 was assigned to the stretching vibration of Cu-O [37]. HPW exhibited characteristic peaks at 800, 891, 983, and 1080 cm−1, which corresponded to W-Oe-W, W-Oc-W, W=Ot, and P-Oa vibrations [38,39]. The broad peak of PMS-15C-x at 1080 cm−1 belonged to SBA-15C, and the characteristic peaks at 730, 1112, 1045, 1372, 1446, and 1643 cm−1 belonged to MOF-199 [40]. Compared with MOF-199@SBA-15C, PMS-15C-x had four more characteristic peaks at 800, 891, 983, and 1080 cm−1, which were due to Keggin-type HPWs, suggesting that the backbone of Keggin-type anions was preserved in the PMS-15C-x. However, the intensities of all these characteristic peaks were lower than those of pure HPW due to the uniform dispersion of HPW and its encapsulation within MOF-199 crystals. The morphology of PMS-15C-0.2 was examined with SEM and TEM. The PMS-15C-0.2 displayed an irregular morphology and had a smooth surface, along with a rod-like structure (Fig. 5 . A). This suggested that the presence of SBA-15C had an influence on the growth of HPW@MOF-199 [37]. As shown in Fig. 5. B, on the surface of PMS-15C-0.2, there was no aggregation of MOF-199@HPW crystals. Fig. 5. C and 5D show the TEM images, in which there were regular, ordered light and dark pores, indicating the presence of ordered nanopores. This demonstrated that the addition of HPW@MOF-199 did not affect the ordered mesoporous structure of SBA-15C, which was consistent with the XRD patterns. [41]. No crystal particles formed via the aggregation of HPW@MOF-199 outside the pores, indicating that most HPW@MOF-199 crystals grew in SBA-15C. The EDX spectrum of PMS-15C-0.2 is shown in Fig. 6 . The surface elemental composition and electronic states of PMS-15C-0.2 were investigated using XPS (Fig. 7 ). As shown in Fig. 7. A, O, Cu, W, Si, and C were detected in PMS-15C-0.2. The bonding energies of Si are shown in Fig. 7. D, with the peaks at 104 eV and 155 eV belonged to Si-O species [42]. The bonding energies of W are shown in Fig. 7. C, with the peaks at 35.5 eV and 37.6 eV belonged to W4f, which were in good agreement with those of W in Keggin-type HPW [43]. The bonding energies of Cu were shown in Fig. 7. B, with the peaks at 935.0 eV and 955.0 eV belonged to Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2, indicating that Cu in the PMS-15C-0.2 composite mainly existed as Cu(II) [42]. However, due to the incorporation of HPW which affected the morphology and crystallinity of MOF-199, the binding energies of Cu in PMS-15C-0.2 shifted compared with MOF-199@SBA-15C, as indicated in Fig. S4. This changed the binding energy of its central element, Cu, indicating that MOF-199 was loaded into PMS-15C-x. After the formation of composites made from HPW, MOF-199, and SBA-15C, the Keggin-type structure of HPW and the ordered mesoporous structure was preserved. The encapsulation of HPW by MOF-199 prevented the easy detachment of HPW during catalytic reactions, and stabilization of MOF-199@SBA-15C was promoted by the combination of MOF-199 and SBA-15C. 3.2 Catalytic performance 3.2.1 Catalytic activity of different materials The catalytic activity of PMS-15C-0.2 was systematically investigated using the reaction of acetic acid and ethanol. For comparison, HPW, MOF-199, SBA-15C, and HPW@MOF-199 were also used as catalysts. The specific reaction conditions were 90 mg catalyst, 0.1 mol ethanol, 0.05 mol acetic acid, reaction time: 12 h, reaction temperature: 80 °C. The evolution of ethyl acetate yield over time for various catalysts employed in the esterification reaction are shown in Fig. 8 . A. In the absence of a catalyst, the low yield of ethyl acetate indicated the critical role of the catalyst in this reaction. For SBA-15C, it was essentially inactive in this reaction. However, the yields of ethyl acetate were 91.3 % and 86.5 % when pure HPW and HPW@MOF-199 were used, but pure HPW could not be easily recycled, and HPW@MOF-199 was less stable. The ethyl acetate yield of 81.4 % with PMS-15C-0.2 as catalyst can be attributed to the following factors. The main reason for this was that the HPW was encapsulated by the caged pores of MOF-199. This encapsulation prevented HPW from leaching out during the reaction and ensured its stability. In addition, the encapsulation promoted synergies between MOF-199 and HPW, further improving the overall catalytic activity [44]. The mechanism was probably attributed to the significant internal surface area of MOF-199, coupled with its hydrophilic properties [45], and the reactants may have been enriched within HPW@MOF-199. Second, the stability and reusability of the material was improved by the combination of SBA-15C and MOF-199. To further verify that PMS-15C-0.2 was a non-homogeneous catalyst, the experiment was conducted by removing the catalyst after 180 min while maintaining the same experimental conditions for the remaining mixture. It was shown in Fig. 8. B that the reaction basically stopped after removing PMS-15C-0.2 and did not continue to produce ethyl acetate. After the reaction, the collected filtrate was analyzed by ICP, which showed the presence of negligible amounts of dissolved W6+ or Cu2+ ions in solution, indicating no significant HPW leaching or damage to the MOF-199 crystals during the reaction. Therefore, the esterification reaction using PMS-15C as a catalyst was likely non-homogeneous and occurred on the loaded PMS-15C solid catalyst rather than in solution. In addition, the same test was done for HPW@MOF-199, but the HPW@MOF-199 was removed at 90 min. The results of the experiments showed that the reaction also basically stopped when HPW@MOF-199 was filtered. 3.2.2 Optimization of reaction conditions In order to systematically analyze the impact of reaction conditions on the esterification of acetic acid and ethanol, the study focused on four key parameters: acid-alcohol molar ratio, HPW addition, catalyst dosage, and reaction temperature. We first investigated the influence of reaction temperature on the esterification reaction of acetic acid and ethanol. As shown in Fig. 9 . A and Table S3, with increasing reaction temperature, both the yield of ethyl acetate and the reaction rate increased. Based on the Arrhenius equation, for endothermic reactions, the reaction rate is positively correlated with temperature. Given that the esterification of acetic acid and ethanol was endothermic, the time for the reaction to reach equilibrium was accelerated, and the conversion rate increased so as the temperature increased. However, as the reaction temperature increased further, the yield of increased insignificantly, so the reaction temperature was set to 80 °C for the next experiments. (A) reaction temperature, (B) acid-alcohol molar ratio, (C) HPW addition and (D) catalyst dosage Esterification is a reverse reaction, and once equilibrium is achieved, the yield of the product will remain essentially the same, and one reagent is often allowed to be in excess to increase the yield [46]. Therefore, we investigated the influence of reactant molar ratio. The yield of ethyl acetate increased from 52.2 % to 81.4 % when the acid-alcohol molar ratio was adjusted from 1:1 to 1:2, as shown in Fig. 9. B and Table S4. When the molar ratio was increased to 1:4, the yield increased to 86.1 %. This indicated that when the molar ratio was 1:2, the reaction was close to equilibrium, and further increasing the acid-alcohol ratio did not greatly promote the forward reaction, so the acid-alcohol ratio for the experiment was set at 1:2. The number of acid active sites directly influences catalytic activity. Therefore, the effect of the amount of PMS-15C-0.2 on the ethyl acetate yield was evaluated. As shown in Fig. 9. C and Table S5, more catalyst led to more active sites in the reaction system, which promoted the esterification process and improved the yield. However, when the amount of catalyst was further increased, the reaction system was saturated with active sites, and the ethyl acetate yield remained essentially unchanged. Therefore, in further studies, the amount of catalyst was set at 90 mg. Finally, the effect of HPW addition on the esterification reaction was investigated. The yield increased from 42.4 % to 81.4 % when the addition of HPW was increased from 0.05 to 0.2 g, as presented in Fig. 9. D and Table S6. This might be due to the fact that as the HPW addition increased, the number of active catalytic sites available for the reaction also increased [47]. But when the amount of HPW was increased to 0.3 g, the yield slightly increased to 85.1 %, possibly because the reaction system was saturated with acid-active sites. Further addition of HPW had little effect on the reaction equilibrium, so the amount of HPW added was set at 0.2 g. In summary, the optimum experimental conditions for the reaction between ethanol and acetic acid were as follows: catalyst PMS-15C-0.2, dosage of 90 mg, 80 °C, and 12 h. The yield of ethyl acetate achieved 81.4 % under the above experimental conditions. And a comparative study of the esterification reactions of acetic acid and ethanol was shown in Table 1 . 3.2.3 Esterification of other mono acids and alcohols To investigate the suitability of the catalyst, PMS-15C-0.2 was also employed in the esterification of acetic acid/n-octanol and oleic acid and ethanol. When 90 mg PMS-15C-0.2 was used as a catalyst, the specific experimental conditions were as follows: 0.05 mol acetic acid, 0.1 mol ethanol, 12 h, and 80 °C; 0.05 mol acetic acid, 0.1 mol n-octanol, 12 h, and 110 °C; 0.05 mol oleic acid, 0.1 mol ethanol, 12 h, and 110 °C. The yields of ethyl acetate, n-octyl acetate, and ethyl oleate, as shown in Fig. 10 , were 81.4 %, 71.5 %, and 41.4 %, respectively. The above results indicated that PMS-15C-0.2 was selective for the reaction of esterification. The above results indicated that PMS-15C-0.2 was selective for the esterification reaction. It was assumed that the reaction mainly took place in the pores of PMS-15C-0.2, it can be inferred that the yield decreased progressively as the carbon chain length increased, which may be owing to steric hindrance [50]. 3.2.4 Reusability study of PMS-15C To test the stability of PMS-15C-0.2, five consecutive cycles were performed under the experimental conditions of 90 mg of PMS-15C-0.2, 0.05 mL of acetic acid, and 0.1 mL of ethanol for 12 h at 80 °C. During the five cycles, the ethyl acetate yield was basically the same during each cycle, remaining around 80 % as shown in Fig. 11 . A and Table 2 . This indicated that during the reuse of the catalyst, PMS-15C-0.2 was not deactivated. For HPW@MOF-199, although its initial catalytic activity was high, and the yield was 86 %, the ethyl acetate yield decreased linearly during cycling to <50 % after 5 cycles. For PMS-15C-0.2, the recovery was 91.2 % while maintaining high activity and the contents of HPW and MOF-199 were also relatively stable. Owing to the absence of SBA-15C carrier protection, the recovery of HPW@MOF-199 was only 52.71 %, and the loss of HPW was serious. And the damage to the structure of HPW@MOF-199 resulted in the loss of the active components of HPW, which in turn led to a lower catalytic activity. The stability of the PMS-15C-0.2 composites mainly originated from interactions between the SBA-15C carrier and MOF-199, in which the carboxyl groups of SBA-15C were involved in the synthesis of MOF-199 but also significantly enhanced the interactions between them. The dimensions of the MOF-199 cage were just large enough to accommodate the HPW molecules, which prevented the loss of HPW active sites. With the above interactions, the detachment of HPW and the destruction MOF-199 during cycling were avoided. After the 5th cycle, the XRD pattern of the sample was shown in Fig. 11. B, which was basically the same as that of unused PMS-15C-0.2, indicating that the structure of PMS-15C-0.2 remained unchanged and was not damaged after the 5th reaction. 3.3 Kinetic analysis of the esterification reaction of acetic acid and ethanol 3.3.1 Reaction rate constants The reverse reaction of acetic acid and ethanol is described by the following chemical equation: (1) C H 3 C O O H + C H 3 C H 2 O H à C H 3 C O O C H 2 C H 3 + H 2 O The esterification reaction can be regarded as the secondary reverse reaction, and the corresponding reaction rate equation can be expressed as: (2) − r A = − d C A / d t = k 1 C A C B − k − 1 C C C D where C A, C B, C C, and C D are the concentrations of acetic acid, ethanol, ethyl acetate, and water, respectively, k 1 is the rate constant for the forward reaction, k -1 is the rate constant for the reverse reaction, the reaction time unit is h, and the concentration unit is mol/L−1. (14) fit the data well. 4 Conclusion The HPW@MOF-199/SBA-15C composite with dual active sites was synthesized by an encapsulation technique, in which HPW was encapsulated within MOF-199. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions, XRD, SEM, and TEM analyses showed that the PMS-15C-x composite had an ordered 2D hexagonal mesoporous structure, and the growth of HPW@MOF-199 in the pores of SBA-15C. FT-IR and XPS analyses indicated the successful loading of HPW and the Keggin-type structure was retained in PMS-15C-x. The catalytic performance of PMS-15C-x composites was studied using the esterification of acetic acid and ethanol. The ethyl acetate yield reached 81.4 % when PMS-15C-0.2 was used as the catalyst in the dosage of 90 mg and the molar ratio of acetic acid and ethanol was 1:2 for 12 h and 80 °C. Moreover, the data fit well with the kinetic model of the secondary reverse reaction. The forward reaction activation energy was 38.35 kJ mol−1 at a range of reaction temperatures from 333 to 373 K. Besides catalyzing the esterification of acetic acid and ethanol, PMS-15C-0.2 was also catalytic for acetic acid and n-octanol as well as oleic acid and ethanol. In addition, PMS-15C-0.2 was selective for the esterified reactants, and the catalytic efficiency decreased with increasing reactant alkyl chain length. The catalytic performance of PMS-15C-0.2 remained stable after five cycles because of the interactions between MOF-199 and SBA-15C, as well as the protection provided by MOF-199 to HPW. This prevented HPW from leaching and preserved the crystal structure of HPW@MOF-199. CRediT authorship contribution statement Yibo Zhang: Writing – original draft, Methodology, Data curation. coredata.dc:description: Metal-organic framework (MOF)-based composites have received significant attention for catalytic applications and are believed excellent heterogeneous catalysts. In this article, we prepared a new type of material, HPW@MOF-199/SBA-15C (PMS-15C). For this material, the MOF-199 encapsulating Keggin-type phosphotungstic acid (HPW) was grown inside the pores of the SBA-15 functionalized by carboxylic acids. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions, X-ray powder diffraction, transmission electron microscopy, and scanning electron microscopy analyses showed that the PMS-15C composites had an ordered two-dimensional hexagonal mesoporous structure, in which HPW encapsulating by MOF-199 loaded into the SBA-15C. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy indicated that HPW was successfully loaded, and the Keggin structure of HPW in PMS-15C remained unchanged. With the reaction of acetic acid and ethanol, the catalytic performance of PMS-15C was studied. Under the optimal conditions, ethyl acetate yield reached 81.4 %. The forward reaction rate was 0.432 mL mol−1 min−1, and the activation energy was 38.35 kJ mol−1. And the data were found to be consistent with the second-order reversible reaction kinetic model. The catalytic activity of the PMS-15C-0.2 composites remained stable after five catalytic cycles. In addition, the esterification of n-octanol/acetic acid and ethanol/oleic acid were studied using PMS-15C-0.2 as the catalyst. The results suggested that the catalytic activity of PMS-15C-0.2 was weakened upon increasing the substrates’ alkyl chain length.
